bestBHT.bht: The encouragement in consideration of the shortness of time until Christ's return is to endure with patience. The prophecy by Habakkuk is fulfilled in Christ, the 'he that cometh.' The Messianic application of 'ο ερχομενος' emphasizes his role as the coming deliverer. The apostle's message is that affliction is not far off from its end, as the Redeemer's appearance is imminent. The hope of a speedy end sustains the afflicted, assuring them that their sufferings will cease soon.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Encouragement to patient endurance by consideration of the shortness of the time till Christ shall come."
He that shall come [referring to Christ]."

Christ, being the grand and ultimate subject of all prophetical vision, is here made by Paul, under inspiration, the subject of the Spirit's prophecy by Habakkuk, in its final and exhaustive fulfillment.
Albert Barnes: The idea which the apostle means to convey evidently is, that the time of their deliverance from their trials was not far remote.

And he that shall come will come - The reference here is, doubtless, to the Messiah... would soon do this. In this way he would put a period to their persecutions and trials, as the power of the Jewish people to afflict them would be at an end.
To all the afflicted it may be said that 'he that shall come will come' soon. The time of affliction is not long. Soon the Redeemer will appear to deliver his afflicted people from all their sorrow.
Marvin Vincent: A little while [μικρον οσον οσον]. Strictly, a very little while."
He that shall come will come [ο ερχομενος ηξει]. Rend. 'he that cometh will come.'
Similarly, he refers hxei shall come to the final coming of Messiah to judge the world.
John Calvin: That it may not be grievous to us to endure, he reminds us that the time will not be long.
There is indeed nothing that avails more to sustain our minds, should they at any time become faint, than the hope of a speedy and near termination.
He that cometh will come, and will not tarry.
Philip Schaff: For yet a very little while...for a little time, how little."
He that cometh 'the coming One'...He was called 'the coming One,' and He is so still.
The day of Jehovah in the one covenant becomes the day of the Lord in the other.
Archibald T. Robertson: A very little while (μικρον οσον οσον).
The article ο is added to ερχομενος in Habakkuk 2:3 and is given here a Messianic application.
John Gill: But in a little while from the writing of this epistle, he, who was to come, did come, even within about ten years after this, and showed his power and his glory, in delivering his people, and destroying his enemies."

The afflictions of the saints are many; they are all for an appointed time, and but for a while; and Christ has promised to come, and visit them; and which he does often, and speedily, and seasonably."

This coming of his is desirable, because it will be the marriage of the Lamb, and the redemption of the saints, and because of the grace and glory that will be brought unto them, and because they shall then be forever with him; and this will be quickly, in a little time, in comparison of the time that went before his first coming, and of the eternity that will follow after this.
John Wesley: He that cometh — To reward every man according to his works.

bhtAttempts.bht: The encouragement given in this verse is to patiently endure the trials and tribulations of life by considering the shortness of time until Christ returns. The prophecy in Habakkuk about he that shall come is ultimately fulfilled in Christ, who is referred to as he that cometh. The use of the article ο in ο ερχομενος emphasizes its Messianic application. The apostle's message is that deliverance from affliction is not far off, for the coming of Christ, the deliverer, is imminent. The hope of the Redeemer's speedy appearance sustains and strengthens the afflicted, assuring them that their sufferings will come to an end.

The encouragement in consideration of the shortness of time until Christ's return is to endure with patience. The prophecy by Habakkuk is fulfilled in Christ, the 'he that cometh.' The Messianic application of 'ο ερχομενος' emphasizes his role as the coming deliverer. The apostle's message is that affliction is not far off from its end, as the Redeemer's appearance is imminent. The hope of a speedy end sustains the afflicted, assuring them that their sufferings will cease soon.

The exhortation in this passage is to endure patiently while remembering that Christ's second coming is not far away. The prophecy in Habakkuk finds its fulfillment in Christ as the he that cometh. The Messianic application of ο ερχομενος highlights his role as the coming one. The apostle's message is that afflictions will soon come to an end as the Redeemer's appearance is imminent. The hope of a speedy resolution sustains the afflicted, reminding them that their sufferings are temporary.

The encouragement given is to endure patiently, considering the nearness of Christ's coming. The prophecy of Habakkuk is fulfilled in Christ, the he that cometh. The Messianic application of this term emphasizes his role as the coming deliverer. The apostle's message is that affliction will not last long since the Redeemer's appearance is imminent. The hope of a swift resolution sustains those who are suffering, assuring them that their tribulations are temporary.

The exhortation is to patiently endure by considering the shortness of time until Christ's return. The prophecy is fulfilled in Christ, the he that cometh. The Messianic application of this title emphasizes his role as the coming deliverer. Affliction will soon come to an end as the Redeemer's appearance is imminent. The hope of a speedy resolution sustains the afflicted, reminding them that their sufferings are temporary.
